awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Dual-Modality Tomography Core Scanner for Oil Saturation Estimation at the Wellsite (iTomoSoS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to make oil exploration and production (E&P) operations less risky and economically and technically more efficient. The new technology has the potential to achieve significant reductions in oil exploration drilling costs.  The technology will also increase long-term commercial benefits for exploration and production companies due to more accurate and reliable estimates of the recoverable reserves and production planning over the decades-long reservoir lifecycle.  These benefits will support global economic growth by ensuring a continued supply of hydrocarbons for the US and internationally during the critical transition to renewable energies. The new technology being developed under this SBIR project will also reduce the environmental impact, energy consumption, and overall carbon footprint of offshore/onshore E&P operations by reducing waste, pollution, and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, thereby directly benefiting future generations. Successful completion of the project will further reinforce the leadership of the US in utilization of advanced hydrocarbon E&P technologies and support the goal of energy independence from global markets by making US producers more effective and competitive.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of determining volumetric (3D) hydrocarbon distribution throughout large-diameter long cores with high spatial resolution (10 mm3), 95% accuracy, and 1 meter/hour throughput at the offshore/onshore wellsite. Today, this is not possible with any technology, i.e., logging data can be used to derive hydrocarbon estimates on a sparse set of points along the wellbore, while “special core analysis” at onshore laboratories takes weeks to complete. Neither of the current techniques can closely match the resolution and accuracy offered by the proposed solution. The disruptive innovation of this development is to combine 3-dimensional (3D) X-ray Multi-Energy Computed Tomography (MECT) and Electrical Impedance Tomography (EIT) in one wellsite core scanning instrument, thereby allowing for novel, synergistic combination of the information provided by the MECT and EIT modalities. Algorithms will be developed to combine the complementary datasets to yield 3D hydrocarbon distribution in the cores in near real-time. These algorithms will be tested on realistic digital core models. The ultimate goal of Phase I is to demonstrate that the specified target accuracy, spatial resolution, and scanning-imaging throughput for assessing 3D distribution of hydrocarbons in large cores can be achieved with the new wellsite instrument.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The key innovation of this project is to combine two tomographic imaging modalities, Dual-Energy Computed Tomography (DECT) and Electrical Impedance Tomography (EIT) to develop and test a novel imaging technology (iTomoSoS) for accurate and high 3D resolution estimation of oil distribution in rock cores utilized during exploration, evaluation, and production operations of energy companies. The iTomoSoS technology leverages advances in 3D Tomographic Imaging, Digital Rock Modeling (DRM), and Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) to provide this needed unique capability at the wellsite as well as in core analysis labs.

DECT core image reconstructions contain density and atomic composition information to accurately distinguish the solid rock matrix from pore space to estimate rock porosity (at DECT resolution). Most of the electrical transport occurs through ions in the pore space (filled with a mixture of conductive brine and nonconductive oil) and other conductive materials of the core. Therefore, EIT image reconstructions complement X-ray CT reconstructions by providing information required to perform estimation of the oil fraction (Fo - the amount of oil in a unit volume of core).

Neither a formula nor an algorithm to predict Fo from DECT and EIT core image reconstructions exists. To address this challenge, iTomography developed the iTomoSoS technology allowing to effectively combine DECT and EIT imaging utilizing an iTomography-designed ANN for oil fraction estimation, Fo-ANN. The Fo-ANN operates in 3D on a given core using the DECT and EIT reconstructions as input as well as a collection of digital pore scale core models that simulate the formation of interest. The Fo-ANN output provides the required high-resolution 3D estimates of Fo.

The iTomoSoS technology was validated via a number of complex numerical experiments involving geologically-sound DRMs. iTomography's partner Equinor energy company provided a data bank of nearly a thousand DRMs that simulated dry cores from several geological formations. iTomography then dispersed brine, oil, and solid impurities to the DRMs. We used these models to simulate DECT and EIT data and to perform 3D image reconstructions to train and test our Fo-ANN and the entire iTomoSoS workflow.

The key conclusions of the development performed during Project are as follows:

  • iTomography demonstrated the feasibility of iTomoSoS to achieve the required high accuracy of Fo estimates (maintaining the error level of less than 0.05 Fo units) at 5-mm spatial resolution.
  • iTomography determined the DECT and EIT data acquisition requirements necessary to maintain this high Fo estimation accuracy.
  • iTomography developed a lab test program for iTomoSoS verification on real core data.

During the next phase of the Project, iTomography will build a prototype of the dual-modality core scanning system and develop a more powerful software to extensively test the iTomoSoS technology on real rock cores from various geological regions.


Last Modified: 12/15/2023
Modified by: Michael Frenkel
